sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 12 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12, the alternating group A4, or the dihedral group D6.
message_1: Suppose G is a group of order 12 with identity element e. Prove that G must contain an element of order 2 and an element of order 3. Moreover, show that if G does not contain any element of order 6, then G is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12 or the dihedral group D6.
message_2:
To prove that G must contain an element of order 2 and an element of order 3, we will use the concept of Sylow subgroups. By the Sylow theorems, G has a Sylow 2-subgroup P of order 4 and a Sylow 3-subgroup Q of order 3. Since the orders of P and Q are prime, they are both cyclic. Let p be an element of order 4 in P and q be an element of order 3 in Q. Then, the order of p is 2 (mod 4) and the order of q is 3 (mod 3). Thus, G contains an element of order 2 and an element of order 3.

Now, let's assume that G does not contain any element of order 6. We will show that G is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12 or the dihedral group D6.

Consider the product of the orders of P and Q, which is 4 * 3 = 12. Since the order of G is 12, by the Sylow theorems, the number of Sylow 2-subgroups divides 3 and is congruent to 1 (mod 2), and the number of Sylow 3-subgroups divides 4 and is congruent to 1 (mod 3). Thus, there can be either 1 or 3 Sylow 2-subgroups and either 1 or 4 Sylow 3-subgroups.

Case 1: There is only one Sylow 2-subgroup and one Sylow 3-subgroup.
In this case, both P and Q are normal subgroups of G. Since the orders of P and Q are relatively prime, their intersection is trivial, i.e., P ∩ Q = {e}. Then, by the internal direct product theorem, G is isomorphic to the direct product of P and Q, which is a cyclic group of order 12. Thus, G is isomorphic to C12.

Case 2: There are three Sylow 2-subgroups and one Sylow 3-subgroup.
In this case, Q is a normal subgroup of G, and G acts on Q by conjugation. Since Q is cyclic, this action is determined by the action of G on the generator q of Q. The action of G on Q induces a homomorphism φ: G → Aut(Q), where Aut(Q) is the group of automorphisms of Q. Since Q has order 3, Aut(Q) is isomorphic to the cyclic group of order 2. The kernel of φ is the centralizer of Q in G, denoted by C_G(Q). Since G does not contain any element of order 6, the centralizer C_G(Q) must be equal to Q. Thus, the image of φ has order 12/3 = 4, and G is isomorphic to a semidirect product of Q and a subgroup of order 4 in Aut(Q). This semidirect product is the dihedral group D6.

In conclusion, if G does not contain any element of order 6, then G is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12 or the dihedral group D6.
